Praeterea quaeri solet
Lombardus, Sent. XXX
. This is distinction 39 in which, after the Master showed how knowledge with respect to things known has causality, here he shows that the knowledge of God from the variation of what is known does not receive variety. And it is divided in three because in the first place he proposes the question, in the second place he adds a response, and the third place his posits an objection. The second begins at
ad quod dicimus
Lombardus, Sent. XXX
. The third at
hic opponitur
Lombardus, Sent. XXX
.

The first and the second remain undivided, but the third is divided into three parts because in the first of these divisions he introduces a twofold objection, in the second he offers the proper response to these objections, in the third reduces or joins the response of the major to these objections. The second begins at
ad quod dicimus potest quid Deus
Lombardus, Sent. XXX
. The third begins at
idem a quibusdam
Lombardus, Sent. XXX
, etc.
Whether just as the divine essence is the cognitive ratio of all future things, so the same that is foreknowledge is the ratio or productive action of future contingents.

That not because no foreknowledge should be put in God, therefore. The antecedent is proved then of the object of this foreknowledge is either true or false. It is not true because every true things is present, but foreknoweldge is only of future things not of present things acorrding to the Master as it stood declared above. Nor is it false because then God would be able to be decieved. In the second place, because foreknowledge as such does not imply a perfection. In the third place, because God is able to be and not be foreknowledge, but however God is able to be he is that way, therefore he is not foreknowledge.

In the second place principally, no contingent future is true, therefore. The antecedent is proved because then it follows that some proposition about a future contingent will be true or false, the opposite of which seems to be proven by
Aristotle, I Perihermenias
Aristoteles, Perihermenias I, xxx.
, and
Aureolus
holds this with him. Then in the second place because everything able to be is, but the future is able to be, therefore it is and consequently it is not future but present. Then in the third place because some common measuring ratio would correspond to the entire latitude of contingency. This consequent is false because since such a ratio is not able to be suitable to a creature, it necessarily suits God, which is false because in God there is no intrinsic contingency.

In the third place principally, no such ratio corresponds to divine foreknowledge with respect to a future contingent, therefore. The antecedent is proved because it is not suitable to him, either that he knows a because then it would necessarily suit him, or that he wishes a because then God would be the cause of future sin. Then in the second place, because the divine effecting does not terminate except into something positive, but the future is not something positive. Then in the third place, because then he would cause freely, and then it would be the case that the divine effects no future, which is false because of the parts of the contradiction the other part is necessarily true.

In opposition, no thing is future from itself nor does something suffice to put itself into being or to produce itself, therefore it requires some productive cause which puts it into being, but not unless there is also God or a passive cause, which is therefore a certain and perfect foreknowledge of all future things.

The first conclusion: though the divine essence according to no perfection absolutely as such is necessary actual knowledge or clarity, nevertheless this is with respect to such a thing ratio freely representing and infallible and also and immeasurable certitude. The first is proved because, if this is so, it follows that necessarily that something is true the divine science would known or that it would be able to lack some perfection absolutely Each consequent is false. And the consequence is clear because this known thing would occur necessarily. The second part is clear through
Augustine, III De civitate Dei, in a chapter , dicentem,
to confess that God is and to deny that he foreknows the future is obviously insane
Augustinus, De civitate Dei V, c. 9
. The conclusion is confirmed in
Matthew 28 et 26
Do you think that I am not able to ask my Father that he will give more than twelve legions of angels?
Matthaeus 26:53 , therefore that Christ does not ask the Father, it was merely free and contingent

First corollary: though every truth is an object of the divine science, nevertheless only a true future as such is the object of foreknowledge. The first is clear because God is the founder and knower of everything. The second is clear because foreknowledge is only said with respect to future things. From this it would be able to be inferred that properly speaking about foreknowing God does not know that the antichrist will be. This is clear because that is not future but present if nevertheless this is something. Nevertheless it should be known that this proposition God foreknows that the antichrist is future and things similar to this are admitted because it is true that God that God knows that the antichrist is not but will be, or according to others God knows this that the antichrist is a thing that will be future. Again, it should be known that having supposed that the antichrist is future, this will be nothing in reality, yet God still knows this because God knows that two gods are not distinct from him and nevertheless that there are not two Gods is nothing. From these things it is clear that the following consequence is not valid, God knows this or this is present, therefore this a real being.

Second corollary: though God according to no ratio is necessary knowledge of a future contingent, nevertheless God according to his essential ratio which is universally perfect is perfect knowledge of any possible future being. The second part is proved because that God is foreknowing the future is part of ratio of perfection, therefore it intrinsically belongs to the divine essence.

Third corollary: though God is not able to resolve completely the entire latitude of possible things into a line of future things, nevertheless God is able to resolve a line of future possible things into a line of things existing presently. The first part is clear because past and present things are able to be called possible, but these things as such are not able to be called future because such things were able not to have been. The second is clear because every possible being is able to be put in the being of existence through God.

The second conclusion: though every future shines in the divine knowledge as if in his art, nevertheless anything contingent thing will be not from necessity. The first part is clear through what is said above. The second part is proved because any future thing that will be occurs contingently from its principle cause, therefore it occurs contingently The consequence holds because, just as the first cause has more influence in the caused than the second cause, so it determines more than the second. And the antecedent is proved because to the outside it acts contingently and freely.

First corollary: though every future just as it is foreknown and all things properly foreknown are future, nevertheless more things than those just those foreknown are able to be future. the first is clear because is foreknowing of all future things and only if they are future things as the first corollary says. The second part is proved because many things are able to be future which de facto are not future which if it were future, then they would be past.

The second corollary: just no future is necessary, so it is not necessarily the case that something is future. This clear because God is able to produce or wish or conserve nothing outside of himself, contra
Bosemblantem, distinction 38 of book 1 in the solution which he offers for the same argument
Bosemblantes, I, d. 38, xxx
.

Third corollary: having supposed that every possible being exists, nevertheless the present future would still exist and the commensurative contingent ratio would not
be able to correspond to the whole latitude of contingency. The first part is clear it does not follow, anything that is able to be future is, the future is able to be, therefore it is. But it ought to be said in the minor premise that the future is because it is able to be which does mean that it is already there. The second part is proved because then such a ratio commensurative of the latitude of contingency would be suitable to God. The consequent is false, and the consequence is clear because it would not be able to suit any creature. From this it is clear that, though in God there is no intrinsic contingency measuring the latitude of contingency, nevertheless the latitude of this contingency is measured through the will of divine liberty or the free rectitude, or though in God there is no intrinsic contingency by which the latitude of contingency is measured, nevertheless the beauty or validity of divine liberty sufficiently measures this latitude of contingency.

Third conclusion: though divine foreknowledge including the divine willing and non-willing or approval of every incomplex being is a formal principle, nevertheless an efficient casual being does not correspond to the divine foreknowledge with respect to what will be future. The first part is clear because the divine efficiency and foreknowledge is the divine will and essence, but the will is the foundational principle of every incomplex being. The second part is proved because the future is nothing, there is no cause of it.

First corollary: if, through the possible or impossible, a future thing were to somehow exist as the cause of divine foreknowledge, nevertheless God would not acquire from this any perfection through its creating operation. This is clear because such a future thing would not be the creating cause of divine foreknowledge, but only the inferring cause. This is the understanding of
Our Doctor Gregory, in question 2 of distinction 38 when solving the first principal argument
Gregorius Ariminensis, Sent. I, d. 38, q. 2
, by saying that it is in the power of man to make it that God eternally knew or wished something. From this it is clear that John of Ripa insufficiently refuted him because he argues against the words but not against his meaning or understanding.
Second corollary: that it is improperly said that the antichrist will be is present or that it is some being. This is clear because it is nothing and consequently it is neither present nor future.

Third corollary: that if foreknowledge is received with the inclusion of the will, and the disposition of the divine, and the future for an incomplex thing, and producibile in itself, then the affirmative part of the conclusion should be held. But if it received as prescinding from these things, then the negative should be held. But if it is understood about a future complex things, then however foreknowledge is understood it is in someway falsely or improperly understood.

Against the first conclusion, it is argued thus: God represents precisely future contingents and is himself necessarily existing by the same ratio, but he represents himself by a necessary ratio, there he does not represent himself freely. The major premise is from
Augustine, XV De Trinitate, chapter 13 , saying,
the Father knows all things in the Word
Augustinus, De Trinitate XV, c. 14, n. 23
, and the minor is clear.
In the second place, every true past is necessary, but any eternally foreknown future is past, therefore.

In the third place, this is valid consequence, Socrates judges that b will occur tomorrow and it will not occur tomorrow, therefore he is deceived. Therefore similarly, Socrates judges that b will occur tomorrow and b is not able to occur tomorrow, therefore Socrates is able to be deceived.

Regarding the second conclusion, that any future contingent is a non-being, therefore no such thing is known or shines in the divine essence, the consequence is valid because according to the
Philosopher I Posterior Analytics ,
of non-being there is no knowledge
Aristoteles, I, Posteriora Analytica XXX
. The antecedent is proved because, if it were being, then either it would be determined in itself or in its own principles/beginnings. Not in itself because what is future should be known. Not the second because such things are not more greatly determined toward one alternative than they are to its opposite, since they are free with respect to each alternative.

In the second place, a future contingent has no truth, therefore. The antecedent is proved because just as each thing is disposed to being, so it is to truth, see
II Metaphysicae
Aristoteles, Metaphysicae
.

In the third place, ever contingent thing
is able to be other disposed, therefore there can be no knowledge or foreknowledge of this kind of thing. The consequence is clear,
for knowledge is of those things that are impossible to be otherwise
Aristoteles, Posteriora Analytica I, c. 2
I Posteriorum . The antecedent is clear from itself.

In the fourth place, if any future were foreknown, then it would follows that we ought not to deliberate about anything. I prove this consequence because there should not be any deliberation about that which will occur determinately, but so it is about anything foreknown, therefore.

Against the third conclusion, it is argued through
proposition 18 of Alexander in de memoria rerum difficilium , where it is said
all knowledge either is the cause of things or caused by things
Alexander, xxxx , but the foreknowledge of God is not caused by things, therefore it is the cause of things.

In the second place, when a non insufferable sufficient cause is posited the effect immediately follows. But the will of God with respect to created things was eternally, therefore creatures were eternally or the will of God with knowledge is not a sufficient cause of things.

In the third place, the nature of contingent things has no certitude in itself, therefore it repugnant for these to be known determinately. The consequence holds because it belongs to the disciplined man to pursue in something only as much certainty as the nature of thing allows. And the antecedent is proved because contingent things are indeterminate and about these things there is no determinate truth, according to the
Philosopher
.

In the fourth place, the knowledge of God is able to be bound to many things and few things, therefore it is variable. The consequence is valid, and the antecedent is proved bot because he is able to foreknow what he does not foreknow, and because he is able to know foreknow what he foreknows. And in the second place because there is not a greater unchangeability in knowledge than in thing known, but in the thing known there is changeability as is known, therefore. The assumed is clear
VII Metaphysics XXX
where it is said that concerning corporeal things there is not able to be knowledge because they are changeable.

To the first, the consequence is denied because, though it represents itself and other things by a necessary ratio, nevertheless the representative ratio of this future is in existence freely and not necessarily

To the second, the major premise is accustomed to be denied when speaking commonly about past things having a relation to future contingents which depend on the coming to be of some future, and thus following kind of difficulties are solved, the soul of Christ knew but it wished or asserted. But against this it is objected that, let it be posited that yesterday the soul of Christ wrote the proposition, I wish a, and it follows that what the soul of Christ wrote yesterday is necessary today. Here some say that the soul of Christ is able to never have written this, But this is rejected because then the past would be able to never have been. Therefore it is said differently, that he asserted this and that he wrote this are not similar cases.

To the third, it is said that the second consequence is not valid because it is not a similar case when both are regarding what is in existence and when they are regarding what is possible See
Scotus, distinction 39, in the solution of the first argument of the second question
Scotus, I, d. 39, xxx
.

To the first against the second conclusion, the consequence is denied because, though they are not beings existing in their own genus, nevertheless they are living in the word or in the first principle, according to what is said in John,
what was made, in him was life
Ioannes 1:3-4 . And this suffices such in order for something to shine in the divine essence.

To the second, it is said that just as an entity is suitable to future things, so the truth is belongs to these same things, for they are entities in the productive principle, and thus also the truth, which is not distinct from the eternal truth.

To the third, the consequence is denied because concerning changeable and corporeal things is a science the
book On generation and corruption
, and about accidental and causative things in
the book of Physics
. In the second place, it is said that to be disposed to impossible things is different than a science with respect to a necessary and unchangeable ratio which is able to be had and formed regarding what it is able to known because the science of God does not depend on known things as our does.

To the fourth, the consequence is denied. And to the proof, it is said that, though the future occurs determinately from God, namely from a principle cause, nevertheless because it is able not to occur, we not take counsel in vain.

To the first against the third conclusion, it is said in the first place that here Alexander understands the term science with inclusion of the divine will and whatever pleases God, and thus the foreknowledge
of God is the cause of things, but not of what is to come because this is not a thing nor something, just as was said above.

To the second, the consequence is denied because, though the will of God is eternal, nevertheless it wished from eternity that a creature were in time and not eternally. And therefore, though the cause of a creature was eternally, nevertheless it was not eternally the cause of a creature or producing a creature.

To the third, it is said that, though for our intellect future things do not have certain evidence, nevertheless for God future things have a determinate truth and are equally, evidently, clearly seen by him, just as when they are will be actually present.

To the fourth, the antecedent is denied. And to the proof, it is said that, though he is able to foreknow what he does not foreknow in the divided sense because what is not future is able to be future, nevertheless science of God is not able to be increased or restricted.
And to the second proof it is said that, though our science is, like known things, is changeable, nevertheless ths is not the case for the science of God which is not caused by things.
To the arguments in the opposition let it be said according to the force of the things that have been said

Praeterea quaeri solet
Lombardus, XXX . First conclusion: that God at the same time and unchangeably knows future good and bad things. Whence his science is not able to be increased or diminished nor changed just as his essence is not able to be changed because his science is his essence. Note nevertheless that the objects of the science of God are able to be increased or diminished.

Second conclusion: that it is well conceded that God would be able to know what he does not know, foreknow what he does not foreknow, not foreknow what he foreknows in the divided but not composite sense because his science is immutabile. And these things suffice from the present lecture.
